title: Solutions to Pell's Equation
description: Pell's equation x^2 - Dy^2 = 1 always has infinitely many solutions when D is not a perfect square, all generated from a unique fundamental solution.

mathlibDependencies.description: All solutions are powers of fundamental

overview.historicalContext: Named after John Pell (1611-1685), though studied earlier by Brahmagupta and Bhaskara II. Lagrange gave the first complete existence proof in 1766-1769. Fermat famously challenged mathematicians with x^2 - 61y^2 = 1.
overview.problemStatement:
**Pell's Equation**:

For any positive integer $D$ that is not a perfect square, the equation
$$x^2 - Dy^2 = 1$$
has infinitely many integer solutions, all generated from a unique fundamental solution $(x_1, y_1)$ by the recurrence $x_n + y_n\sqrt{D} = (x_1 + y_1\sqrt{D})^n$.
overview.proofStrategy: Use the theory of continued fractions and Dirichlet's approximation theorem to establish existence. The multiplicative group structure in Z[sqrt(D)] shows all solutions are powers of the fundamental.
keyInsights: Connected to units in algebraic number rings

sections.title: Existence of Solutions
sections.summary: Proof that non-trivial solutions always exist when D is not a perfect square.

sections.title: The Fundamental Solution
sections.summary: Definition and uniqueness of the fundamental (minimal positive) solution.

sections.title: Generating All Solutions
sections.summary: Every solution is a power of the fundamental solution.

sections.title: Explicit Examples
sections.summary: Verification of solutions for D = 2, 3, 5, 7, and Fermat's challenge D = 61.

conclusion.summary: Pell's equation is fully characterized: infinitely many solutions exist for non-square D, all generated from a unique fundamental solution via the multiplicative structure of Z[sqrt(D)].
